text:
Dear Editor,

As a middle school student, I believe that computers have a predominantly positive impact on people, and the advantages that they bring far outweigh their disadvantages. Firstly, computers can enhance one's skills in hand-eye coordination. Playing video games and typing on the keyboard require precise hand movements and good control over the mouse or touchpad, thus developing a person's motor skills.

Moreover, computers provide people with the ability to learn about faraway places and people. One can simply research any topic of interest online and learn about it in-depth. This enhances a person's knowledge and broadens their understanding of the world, which is essential in today's interconnected global society.

Furthermore, computers enable people to interact with others online through social media and video calls. This facilitates communication with people from different cultures, promotes understanding, and strengthens bonds with family and friends who live far away. In today's fast-paced world, technology is the connective tissue that keeps us together.

While some critics argue that computers take away from outdoor activities, research has indicated that people still engage in physical activity, regardless of their computer use. In fact, some studies suggest that technology can actually motivate people to exercise more by providing accessible exercise programs and motivation through fitness trackers.

In conclusion, computers have several advantages that benefit people in their daily lives. They aid the development of essential skills, provide knowledge about the world, and facilitate communication with others. As a society, we must continue to embrace advances in technology and harness its full potential.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]

Dear Editor,

As a student who has grown up in the age of computers, I strongly believe that these devices have had a positive impact on our society. Indeed, computers have brought about a multitude of benefits that have greatly improved our lives. From education to communication, computers have revolutionized the way we interact with the world around us.

One of the most significant advantages of computers is their ability to provide access to information on a global scale. Whether it be through the internet or educational software, computers give people the ability to learn about faraway places, gain knowledge, and engage with other cultures. I, myself, have had the opportunity to communicate with people from all over the world through online forums and websites. These interactions have broadened my understanding of the world and enriched my life.

Moreover, computers have made education more accessible and efficient. Students are now able to learn at their own pace and explore topics that pique their interests. Education software and online resources have become essential tools in the classroom, enabling teachers to deliver their lessons with greater impact and effectiveness.

Of course, critics argue that using computers too much can lead to social isolation and a lack of physical activity. But, in reality, the issue is not the computers themselves, but how they are being used. With proper time management and moderation, it is entirely possible to balance computer usage with other healthy activities, such as exercise and social interactions.

In conclusion, while it is true that there are some concerns about the negative effects of human dependence on computers, I believe that the positives far outweigh the negatives. Computers have given us the ability to connect with the world, access information, and learn in new and innovative ways. Therefore, I would encourage the readers to embrace technology and use it responsibly for the benefit of both themselves and society as a whole.

Sincerely,

This creates a level playing field for students from all backgrounds.

Computers connect people and have made communication extremely convenient. With just a few clicks, people can talk to friends and family across the world via video calls, voice messages, or emails. This helps strengthen relationships and even contributes to encouraging global peace and understanding by allowing people to learn about different cultures.

Additionally, computers provide a wide range of entertainment options. They can be used to listen to music, watch movies and TV shows, play games and read books. Gone are the days when people had to rely on traditional media for entertainment. Computers provide a whole new world of entertainment options that cater to everyone's unique preferences.

Of course, some people argue that computers have a negative impact on society since they can lead to a sedentary lifestyle. However, this is not the computer's fault. It is essential to balance computer usage with outdoor activities, exercise, and social interaction with people.

In conclusion, computers have a positive effect on society. They have changed the way we learn, communicate, and entertain ourselves. While there are some downsides to computer usage, the benefits are far greater. Let us use computers responsibly for the betterment of society.

Dear Editor,

I am writing this letter to express my views on the effects of computers on people. In this digital age, there is little doubt that computers have brought significant changes to our lives. Some people see this as a positive development, while others argue that it's harmful to our society. From my perspective, I am inclined to believe that the advantages of computers far outweigh any potential negative effects.

Firstly, computers are an excellent tool for teaching and learning. They provide unparalleled access to information that was once only available in libraries, textbooks, and encyclopedias. Now, with just a few clicks, anyone can learn about any subject they are interested in. Additionally, computers provide virtual classrooms to students who would otherwise have difficulty attending, giving them the opportunity to learn and gain new skills.

Secondly, computers have made our lives more convenient. We can shop, do our banking, and even pay our bills online, all from the comfort of our homes. This saves us time and offers greater flexibility in our day-to-day lives.

Lastly, computers act as a connector. With social media, online forums, and chat rooms, people across the globe can communicate with each other, bridging cultural gaps and fostering better understanding. This has brought about new friendships and business connections, and even helps people find potential romantic partners.

However, there are those who argue that computers have adverse effects on our physical and social well-being. They claim that people spend too much time on their computers, leading to a sedentary lifestyle and lack of physical activity, which is accurate to some extent. While it is true, we should be conscious of the amount of time we spend in front of our screens. We can impose a limit on ourselves by setting aside time for outdoor activities, sports, and socializing with our family and friends.

In conclusion, while it's true that computers have some undesirable effects, they have many more advantages to our lives. They have revolutionized industries, created new avenues for expression and creativity, and brought significant progress to our society. Therefore, I believe we should encourage and embrace the use of computers in our daily lives and continue to push for further technological advances.

Sincerely,

text:
Dear Editor,

I am writing in response to the ongoing debate on the impact of computers on society. While some argue that computers have a positive effect on people, I believe that they have more negative than positive effects.

It is true that computers can teach hand-eye coordination and provide access to information from faraway places, but these benefits are outweighed by the detrimental effects they have on people's physical and social well-being. The rise of sedentary lifestyles due to excessive computer use has led to an increase in obesity, diabetes, and other health problems. Moreover, people's addiction to computers has led to a decline in face-to-face communication and social interaction. This has resulted in a negative impact on mental health, especially in teenagers, who are spending too much time online or playing video games, and not enough time socializing or participating in extracurricular activities.

Additionally, the widespread use of computers has also led to the loss of jobs, especially in industries where automation is now possible. This has resulted in higher levels of unemployment and poverty, as people struggle to find new sources of income.

It is, therefore, time for us to reflect on the negative effects of computers and take steps to mitigate them. Parents need to monitor their children's computer use and encourage them to engage in physical activities and face-to-face communication. As an avid reader and regular visitor to my local library, I strongly believe that censorship in libraries is not the solution to protecting young minds from inappropriate content. While it is understandable that some parents may want to shield their children from certain materials, removing access to books, music, movies, and magazines that may be deemed offensive is not the answer.

Firstly, censorship is a slippery slope to limiting intellectual freedom. If we start removing books and other materials that some find offensive, where do we draw the line? Soon, anything that goes against popular opinion or challenges societal norms could be censored. This would limit our access to diverse viewpoints and perspectives, and hinder our ability to think critically and form our own opinions.

Secondly, it is ultimately up to parents to monitor what their children are exposed to. Libraries are not responsible for policing what young readers check out. Instead, parents should actively engage with their children about books and materials they find inappropriate, and work to educate them on what is considered acceptable for their age group.

Furthermore, censorship ignores the fact that what is considered offensive or inappropriate is subjective. One person's idea of offensive content may not be the same as another's. Rather than blanket censorship, we need to foster open discussions and debates about what is and is not appropriate in different contexts.

Lastly, the responsibility of libraries is to provide access to information and materials that reflect diverse perspectives and experiences. Censorship can limit this access and prevent people from discovering books and other materials that could enrich their lives.

In conclusion, censorship in libraries is not the solution to protecting young minds. It limits intellectual freedom, ignores parental responsibility, is subjective, and hinders access to diverse experiences and perspectives. Instead, we should encourage open discussions and debates about appropriate content, and work to educate children and parents on responsible reading habits. As Katherine Paterson said, if we start removing books from the shelves, we risk losing all access to the amazing world of literature.

The library is meant to be a haven of knowledge, a place where readers can pursue their interests and broaden their horizons. I firmly believe that censorship in libraries is detrimental to the pursuit of intellectual freedom and personal growth.

Firstly, censorship stunts intellectual curiosity and critical thinking skills. By only allowing certain materials, we limit our exposure to diverse perspectives and challenging ideas. For example, if books about LGBTQ+ individuals are removed from shelves due to their content, then a young person struggling with their own identity may never find these resources that could be profoundly comforting and enlightening. Thus, censorship can deny young people the opportunity to expand their worldviews by depriving them of exposure to materials that would challenge their preconceptions.

Secondly, censorship undermines the very nature of democratic societies, where the free exchange of ideas is necessary for informed decision-making. Banning materials is a form of suppression, sending the message that there is only one acceptable perspective. By protecting certain groups from 'offensive’ materials, we limit the scope of public discourse, making it difficult for individuals to engage empathetically with diverse perspectives.

Finally, censorship inhibits personal growth by forcing individuals to remain in their comfort zones, shielded from confronting difficult issues head-on. Reading about challenging or uncomfortable topics helps people develop empathy and understanding for issues outside their personal experience, and create new perspectives.

In conclusion, libraries are essential spaces for intellectual growth and exploration, and censorship within them is limiting and counterproductive to these ideals. text:
Censorship in Libraries: Removing Offense or Harmful Materials?

In our society, we seem to have an insatiable desire to control what others can and cannot see, read or hear. But when it comes to censorship in libraries, the issue can be controversial. Some believe that certain materials, like books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed if they are found offensive, while others argue that censorship is a violation of fundamental rights. 

Personally, I believe that censorship in libraries is not effective and should be avoided. Here are some reasons why: 

Firstly, censorship restricts freedom of expression. Every person, regardless of their age, is entitled to read, listen, and watch stories that challenge and expand their thinking. When we ban certain books or movies, we limit the ability of people to learn about different perspectives or explore new ideas. For instance, a study discovered that the most commonly banned book in the USA, To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee, was removed from shelves because it contained racial slurs. However, this book has helped many readers learn about and develop empathy for those who are marginalized due to the color of their skin. Banning it eliminates an opportunity for many to learn about issues on an emotional and intellectual level. 

Secondly, censorship is often arbitrary and can be influenced by personal values or ideology. One person's definition of "offensive" may differ from another's. For instance, a book like Harry Potter, which has been criticized for its portrayal of witchcraft and magic, may be deemed inappropriate or dangerous by some religious groups. However, others view it as active encouragement for young readers to be imaginative and creative. To relinquish the decision of what to read or to watch to one person or group is to disregard the diverse opinions and beliefs. 

Lastly, censorship is against the ethical standards of the library system. Public libraries exist to provide equal access to knowledge, education and entertainment for all members of society, regardless of their social, economic or cultural background. When they remove books or other materials, they deny access to certain knowledge or stories that might be relevant, interesting or important to members of the community, a deprivation of their rights. For example, the book @DR Seuss Goes to War was removed from shelves because it was considered harmful to German-Americans, even though it explains how Seuss became an anti-racist in the USA during World War Two. 

In conclusion, censorship in libraries may seem like a safeguard against offensive or harmful materials, but in reality, it is ineffective, arbitrary, and against the purpose of public libraries. As Paterson argues, it is impossible to pick and choose what should and should not be read or viewed. Instead, we should allow people to make choices for themselves, and always defend the principle of freedom of expression.

text:
Censorship in Libraries: Why We Need to Preserve the Right to Read

As a student, avid reader, and future citizen, I strongly believe that censorship in libraries is a dangerous practice that must be avoided at all costs. The idea of limiting access to books, music, movies, magazines, and other materials because some people find them offensive or controversial goes against the basic principles of intellectual freedom, diversity, and democracy that are the foundations of our society.

First of all, censorship can lead to ignorance and intolerance. By shielding students and other library users from ideas, perspectives, and realities that challenge their beliefs or expose them to different cultures, social issues, and historical events, we risk creating a narrow-minded and prejudiced populace that lacks critical thinking skills, empathy, and curiosity. We also deny people the opportunity to learn about themselves, their communities, and the world in all its complexity, and to engage in meaningful conversations and debates that could promote mutual understanding and respect.

Secondly, censorship violates the rights of individuals to explore and express their own identities, interests, and values. Every person has the right to read, listen, watch, and create whatever they want, as long as they do not harm others or break the law. By imposing our own standards of morality or decency on others, we deny them the autonomy, dignity, and creativity that are essential to human flourishing. We also risk imposing a double standard: if we allow certain groups or individuals to decide what is acceptable or not, based on their own biases or interests, we create a situation of inequality, oppression, and censorship by proxy.

In addition, censorship is often based on misconceptions, stereotypes, and fear. Some people may label certain materials as "dangerous," "immoral," or "inappropriate" without even reading, watching, or listening to them. Others may assume that certain topics or themes are unsuitable for certain ages, genders, races, or religions, without considering the diversity and complexity of human experiences. As a student in grade 9th, I believe that censorship in libraries is a violation of our fundamental right to access information and restricts our freedom of expression. It is not ethical to impose one's personal views or beliefs onto others and curb their right to access information. text:
The Empire State Building was built to be the tallest building in the world, but the plan of adding a mooring mast to accommodate passengers on dirigibles posed many obstacles to the architects and engineers. One of the major challenges was the strain a docked airship would place on the building’s frame. The dirigible’s load and the wind pressure would have to be transferred all the way to the building’s foundation, more than a thousand feet below. The steel frame of the building would need to be strengthened and modified for use as a docking facility.
Another challenge was the weather conditions, with strong winds on top of the building making it difficult to anchor a dirigible blade onto the mast. Dirigibles could be blown over skyscrapers, and lead weights could not be hung to the back of a docked airship because of the risk of them falling on pedestrians below. Additionally, the use of hydrogen in dirigibles, which was flammable and explosive, raised safety concerns.
Finally, the existing law against airships flying too low over urban areas effectively made it illegal for ships to tie up at the Empire State Building. Despite attempts to fix the obstacles, the mooring mast never fulfilled its intended purpose, and it was eventually abandoned in favor of utilizing airplanes. Today, the rooms that were intended for the disembarking of dirigible passengers have never been open to the public, instead, they house a soda fountain and tea garden.

However, the idea of being able to dock with a dirigible presented several obstacles.

Secondly, the German dirigible Hindenburg was destroyed by fire in Lakehurst, New Jersey, on May 6, 1937, which illustrated the high risk of using hydrogen-filled airships in busy, built-up areas. Finally, existing laws forbid airships from flying too low over urban areas, which make it illegal not only for the airship to tie up to the building, but also to approach the area.

In conclusion, the fate of the mooring mast was doomed from the beginning, although the architects envisaged it as more than ornamental. The rooms intended for dirigible passengers were later made into a soda fountain and a tea garden for sightseers visiting the observation decks. I come from a large family, and my sister's wedding was no exception. The wedding was taking place on @DATE, and the preparations were in full swing. The wedding venue was located in a beautiful @LOCATION, nestled amongst tall trees that provided the perfect shade on a hot summer's day. The ceremony was set to take place at @TIME in the afternoon, and everyone was bustling around ensuring everything was perfect.

As the family of the bride, it was our responsibility to ensure that everything went smoothly. This included arranging the decorations, seating, and overseeing the catering. We were doing a great job until we realized that one of the dishes for the buffet table had completely run out! It was only @TIME until the ceremony, and we had no backup plan. The staff at the @ORGANIZATION were in a major panic, and so were we. It was at this point that my cousin, who is known for being the class clown, decided to intervene.

He decided to take things into his own hands and made a joke about the situation. He started pretending to be a waiter, going around the room with an empty tray, asking people if they would like some of his "famous air soup" as a substitute. The situation was so absurd that people began to laugh uncontrollably. The tension in the air dissipated, and everyone began to relax.

As it turns out, the caterers were able to whip up an alternative dish within a few minutes, and before we knew it, the buffet table was full of all kinds of delicious delicacies. However, the mood in the room had entirely shifted thanks to my cousin's silly antics.

It wasn't just the immediate situation that was diffused; the mood at the wedding party had taken on an entirely new trajectory. People who were previously strangers were now chatting, laughing and simply enjoying each other's company. The wedding party atmosphere had changed from one of stress and chaos to one of relaxation and joy.

The rest of the wedding went off without a hitch, and the bride and groom couldn't stop thanking us enough for making their special day perfect. But, that snippet of time where my cousin's antics had the whole place laughing and lightening the mood was an invaluable moment that we will all cherish.

As the evening came to a close, we all danced the night away, each of us with smiles on our faces. The wedding party had brought people from across the country and world together. Yet, it was that single moment that we shared as a family that became its highlight, thanks to a moment of laughter.

The power of humor cannot be overstated. In this instance, it transformed what could have been a catastrophic event into a hilarious moment – and ultimately created a memorable part of my sister's wedding. I learned that when things get difficult, or when we feel like there is no solution, sometimes taking a humorous approach is the best course of action. Laughter truly can be the shortest distance between two people as it has the power to break down barriers, bonds people together, and create some of the most wonderful memories.

About halfway through the trip, we found ourselves stuck in a particularly grueling traffic jam on a hot day in the middle of Nevada. The air conditioning in our car had broken earlier in the trip, and tensions were running high as we sat in the sweltering heat for hours on end.

As the hours wore on, my siblings and I began to get restless and bored. We had exhausted all of our usual car games and were getting cranky and irritable from the heat and lack of movement. It seemed like we were doomed to suffer in silence for the rest of the drive.

That's when my dad, always the joker, suggested we try a new game. He called it "the impersonation game" and explained that we would all take turns doing our best impressions of famous people or characters.

The game got off to a slow start – my little brother's impression of Spongebob Squarepants fell flat and my attempt at Yoda was more funny than accurate – but as we warmed up to the idea, the game became a hilarious highlight of the trip.

We took turns doing impressions of everyone from Donald Trump to Kermit the Frog, with each performance more outrageous and gut-busting than the last. As we laughed and laughed, a sense of camaraderie and joy spread throughout the car, breaking down the barriers of irritation and boredom that had threatened to divide us.

By the time we finally made it to our hotel that night, we were all exhausted but filled with a sense of togetherness and happiness. We even continued the game over dinner, to the bemusement of nearby diners.

Over the course of the rest of the trip, we continued to turn to laughter as a way to ease tensions and connect with each other. We found ourselves making silly jokes and coming up with ridiculous nicknames for each other, rather than snapping at each other in frustration.

Looking back on that trip, I'm struck by how something as simple as a game of impersonations could have such a profound impact on our family dynamic. text:
Laughter is an essential part of any relationship, whether it's between friends, family, or romantic partners. It can break the ice, ease tension, and bring people closer together. I realized this fact one summer day when my family and I went camping in the mountains. 

It was a hot day when we arrived at the campsite, and we were excited to start setting up our tent. My parents, my older brother, and I had brought all the necessary equipment - a tent, sleeping bags, cookware, and plenty of food. We worked together to pitch the tent and set up the camping chairs around the small fire pit. As we sat down to rest, we heard a rustling in the bushes nearby. 

Suddenly, a small bear cub emerged from the underbrush and started sniffing around our campsite. We froze in our seats, not sure what to do. My dad stood up slowly, trying not to startle the cub, and began to back away. But as he moved, the bear cub followed him, getting closer and closer to our tent. 

As we watched in shock, my dad started to back away faster, and the bear cub started to chase him. My brother and I looked at each other, unsure of what to do, while my mom covered her mouth in surprise. Suddenly, my dad tripped over a rock and fell to the ground with a thud. 

At that moment, the bear cub stopped chasing him and ran back into the woods, disappearing from sight. We all let out a sigh of relief and looked at my dad to make sure he was okay. He sat up slowly, rubbing his elbow where it had hit the ground. And then, unexpectedly, he started to laugh. 

It was a strange and infectious laugh, the kind that makes you laugh too, even if you don't know why. And soon, we were all laughing, even my dad, who had just narrowly escaped being chased by a bear cub. We laughed until our sides hurt and tears streamed down our faces. It was a surreal moment, but one that brought us closer together as a family. 

From that day on, we had a standing joke - whenever we saw a bear or heard one in the distance, we would all yell, "Bear!" and start laughing. It became a running gag that lasted the entire camping trip, and even after we returned home. Whenever one of us needed a pick-me-up or a laugh, we would yell "Bear!" and start laughing hysterically, even if there was no actual bear in sight. 

That summer, I learned the power of laughter. It was the glue that held us together, even in scary or tense situations. It brought us closer as a family, and it reminded us to enjoy the small moments in life. We couldn't control when or where a bear might show up, but we could control how we reacted. And by choosing to laugh instead of panic, we created a happy memory that will stay with us forever. 

In conclusion, I believe that laughter is an essential part of any relationship, whether it's with friends, family, or romantic partners. It has the power to break down barriers, ease tension, and create happy memories that will last a lifetime. And even in scary or dangerous situations, laughter can be the thing that saves us. So the next time you find yourself in a tense or awkward moment, try laughing. You might be surprised at how much it can help.

We had to climb over rocks and maneuver our way around fallen trees. At one point, I slipped and fell into a mud puddle. I was covered from head to toe in mud. My family couldn't stop laughing. It was the best thing that had happened all weekend.

We finally arrived at the lake, and it was breathtaking. The water was crystal clear and looked inviting. We all jumped in and started to swim around. My mom had brought along a waterproof camera to capture the moment. We were all having a blast, and my brother suggested a game of Marco Polo. It was my turn to be "it," and as I was blindly swimming around, I ended up bumping into a floating log. My family burst out laughing again. They said I looked like a beaver trying to take down a tree.

After a fun day at the lake, we headed back to our campsite to start a fire and cook dinner. We were excited to try out our new portable grill. However, after several attempts, we couldn't get it to light. Frustrated and hungry, we decided to cook our hamburgers over an open flame. My dad took charge of grilling, but he got a bit carried away. He accidentally set one of the patties on fire. We all started screaming and jumping around, trying to put out the fire. My dad finally managed to extinguish it, and we all fell onto the ground in fits of laughter. We ended up eating burnt burgers, but it was still the best meal we had ever had.

That evening, we decided to play a game of cards. We all made jokes and teased each other throughout the game. My mom kept getting yelled at for cheating, even though she wasn't. My brother was trying to sneak a peek at my cards, but I caught him every time. We were all having so much fun that we didn't even realize how late it had gotten. Before we knew it, it was well past midnight and we were all exhausted.

The next morning, it was time to pack up and head home. As we were taking down our tent, we noticed that a family of squirrels had made a nest in the tree above us. They kept throwing acorns at us, and we couldn't help but laugh. We had experienced so much laughter on this camping trip that it was hard to leave. As we drove away, we all looked at each other and smiled. We knew that we had made some unforgettable memories.

Laughter really is the shortest distance between two people. It brings us closer and creates bonds that last a lifetime. This camping trip was proof of that. Even through the challenges and mishaps we faced, we never lost our sense of humor. And in the end, it was the laughter that we remembered the most.
